p.s: In the Sonnet 116, creates he speaker the idea of an unlimited, stabilestable, strong love, which exists till death and is stronger than every storm.
This idea of love gets supported in different way through the use of structure and language.
First of all, the sonnet's structure is based on the Shakespearean form: It is divided into three quatrains, for each four lines, and a closing couplet, two lines only.
It follows, that the sonnet, with in total 14 lines, is written in the iambic pentameter and has rhyme-scheme abab cdcd efef gg.
The structure of the sonnet supports the idea of the speaker's love in the way, that it devidesdivides the sonnet's sections in what love actually is and what it shouldn't be.
So the first and the third quatrain deal with the negation (what love isn't) and only the second quatrain deals with the information, what love really is.
As well as that, this not only supports and highlights the direct definition of love in the second quatrain (cf. vv. 5-8), but it also emphasizes the climax in the sonnet.
For example is the change of love and the alteration of life - less an abstacle or a problem thenthan the end of your own life, due to an not changeable happening - death.

So these both quatrains also stay in contrast with each other: first of all, (quatrain one) love shouldn't fade away, because of change and obsticlesobstacles in life and love, but the only thing love can be stopped by is a not stoppable event (quatrain three).
In addition to that, the closing couplet highlights the conclusion of the speaker by the seperationseparation of the last two verses.
So the speaker's idea gets proved, because every man loved once and he writes poetry (love poems).
This shows and emphasizes, that everything he mentioned in the quatrains before gets varifiedverified, because the speaker himself nowsknows the effects of love.
Lastly the rhyme schemascheme highlights the seperationseparation of the quatrains and the closing couplet.
It also shows (again) the importance of the closing couplet by repetingrepeating the ending twice (gg).
But not only the structure of the sonnet, also the word fields underline the idea of love being strong, limitless and unchangableinchangeable.
Firstly many words around the topic seafaring get used, exspeciallyespecially in the second quatrain.
Therefore love is aan ever-fix√®d mark (v. 5), or wandering bark (v. 7) and tempests (v. 6) get mentioned.
Secondly the first quatrain contains words around the word field obstacles and change alters (v. 3), bends (v. 4) and impediments (v. 2), which highlights the fact what love shouldn't be.
In the last quatrain you can find words around the topic time.
For example time's fool (v. 9), sickle's compass come (v. 10) and edge of doom (v. 12).
These imageries underline the fact, that love shouldn't be bounded on time but you should enjoy the time you have with your loved one.
Furthermore, there are many stylistic devices used to support the idea of an guiding and strong love.
First of all starts the sonnet with a personification (cf. v. 1) and ana negation.
This hightlights the fact, that love isn't a marriage inwhich only compromised are made and every part of the relationship is unhappy.

Furthermore, with the use of an antithesis and negation love is not love (v. 2) and two anaphoras (cf. v. 3f.), the speaker underlines that real love is based on unlimited focus on one person and that it isn't real of one partner in the relationship is constantly searching for change and alters his mind.
The person, who searches for change, gets presented or stays in focus and somebody, who actively isn't interested in love and is the cause of any problematics.
Furthermore isn't it real and deep love he's feeling, because he is searching for alternatives for focussing on the person, aan anaphora gets used as well (cf. v. 4).
The second quatrain starts with an exclamation (cf. v. 5), to point out the contrast between the second and the first quatrain and that now love as what it is gets described.
Wither the use of ana metaphor ever-fixed mark (v. 5) gets the idea of love as something shining and therefore positively, strong and solid supported.
This gets also verrifiedverified by another metaphermetaphor in verse six: the star guides the lost boats through the night, savelysafely because it stays an bir fixed plays.
This means, that love is a feeling or a person who/which gives you trust and security, which/who guides you and helps you through fifferent and heard situations.
It follows that the metaphor of the wondering bark (v. 7) is also a symbolesymbol for the once, who feel lost in life or other situations and whoswhose only help are security and love.
As well as that gets the landmark/stark, therefore loves, personificated.
This personification, (cf. v. 6), as well as that another metaphor (cf. v. 6), support, that real love should overcome any discussions and problematics easily.
In this case the tempests (v. 6) is a metaphor for any discussions and the dact that the landmark is never shaken the personification (v. 6).

But, even if love give security, no one knows how to find the night one to partner with, and even if you find your loved one, you can ffel disappointed or sad, because you feel no distanced between you and you love.
So that you have the feeling of reaching this person, but can't build up a connection, became you don't know theretheir value.
This idea also getgets supported by different stylistic devices: two alliterations (v. 8), ana contrast (v. 8) and a metaphor (v. 8).
The metaphor shows the not existing distance based on room between two persons and the alliteration with the antithesis show, that there is a distance, because the lover doesn't know the values.
In the last quatrain again, negation supports the idea of love (cf. v. 9).
But this time the negation gets supported by the use of a metaphor and personification - time's fool (v. 5).
This shows, that's real love isn't dependenddependent on time and is limitless.

Even if following the contrast shows the end of the unlimited love through death this also getgets highlighted through different stylistic devices: an antithesis (cf. v. 9), a symbolesymbol for the death (cf. v. 10) and another metaphor (cf. v. 9), standing for the life in contrast to the death, meaning, that everything ro lively needs to die, love doesn't alter.
In fact of you really love someone death connectesconnects the partner even more, becuas they stay together till the end (cf. v. 12).
The idea of this connection getgets supported by a metaphor, too (cf. v. 12).
But this methaphormetaphor edge of doom (v. 12) stays in contrast to the first metaphor, because the meaning of death is more positive and connected with an afterlife.
Lastly, the importance of the closing couplet gets highlighted by the use of parallelism (v. 14).
Therefore real love exists, because if it would get proven wrong, this speaker would write love poems or nobody would love.

In summary the idea of a story unbreakable and romantic Love gets mainly emphasized by metaphors and symbols, representing love as a star and therefore as a guide, also by negations, to show what love isn't.
